p: The tubers of D. hatagirea show wide utilization in silk industries for sizing material [ 102]. The plants are grown in gardens for decorative purposes. The aesthetically appealing appearance of the flowers makes them suitable for ornamental purposes (placed in flower vases, twisted within hair ponies, making bracelets and necklaces). Grounded stem and leaves are used as insect repellant. Leaves and stem of the plant are used as fodder for livestock. D. hatagirea helps in improving the flavor and taste, color and appearance, body and texture, and melting quality of frozen milk products. Moreover, young leaves and shoots are also used as vegetables [ 103]. Extract of the flowers is used in perfume industries to increase fragrance. Tubers of the plants are used for witchcraft [ 77].
